subject: DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
8th October 2019 

TRADE

China is ready to do a deal on the parts of the negotiations both sides agree upon and are prepared to set out a timetable for the harder issues to be worked out next year, according to Fox citing the Chinese Commerce Ministry. The Chinese Commerce Ministry said what is not in the table and never will be is changes to their laws to protect intellectual property, adding the Chinese will deal with IP theft through administrative regulations, according to FBN's Edward Lawrence. (Twitter) US President Trump says if anything bad happened in Hong Kong, it would be bad for US/China trade talks. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department confirms it is naming 28 Chinese governmental and commercial organisations - including Hikvision - to the entity list over treatment of the Muslim Uighur community, effective Monday. (Newswires)

China is still buying US soybeans as trade talks resume, recently making its largest purchase of the agricultural product in more than a year. (WSJ)

NEC Director Kudlow said the delisting of Chinese Co's is not on the table. He does think that the impeachment controversy is having an effect on trade negotiations with China; says further progress could be made later this week and he is open to see what China brings to the table (Newswires)

US

Fed's Kashkari (Dove, Non-voter) said he does not yet know by how much more the Fed should cut rates. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

A leaked document reportedly details the EU's point-by-point rejection of PM Johnson's Brexit proposals, the Guardian reports. (Guardian)

UK and EU negotiators will be meeting tomorrow morning, according to Buzzfeed's Nardelli. (Twitter)

UK Junior Trade Minister Burns said the UK's final no deal Brexit tariffs will be published shortly. (Newswires)

Source close to Tory Brexit rebels says they do not expect to back any attempt to take over Commons business before parliament prorogued Tues eve, according to Huffington Post's Singh - in line with earlier reports. (Newswires)

EU is to mull an alternative to the China "Belt and road" initiative. (Newswires)

Petition designed to achieve a court order to force PM Johnson to seek a Brexit extension has been dismissed; Court says campaigners have not made their case, appeal is expected to be heard on Tuesday., Sky's Matthews. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS 

US President Trump warns Turkey that if it does anything "off limits" he will destroy and obliterate their economy. Meanwhile, there were reports of a Turkish airstrike on Kurdish forces on the border of Syria and Iraq, according to ELINT news. Kurdish town Al-Malikiyah in northern Syria is under Turkish artillery shelling, according to ELINT News. (Twitter)

EU Council President Tusk said Turkey's continued illegal drilling activities undermine relations between the EU and Turkey. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

 

Russian Energy Minister Novak said that Russia have developed spare oil capacity of approx. 0.5mln BPD during the OPEC+ cuts. (Newswires)

US Energy Secretary Perry says he is not stepping down following last week’s source reports. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

 

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 -0.5% at 2939, NASDAQ-100 -0.4% at 7725, Dow Jones -0.4% at 26478 * SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  -0.4%, Consumer Staples  -0.8%, Energy  -0.9%, Financials  -0.5%, Health Care  -0.4%, Industrials  -0.5%, Information Technology  -0.5%, Materials  -0.3%, Telecommunication Services  0%, Utilities  -0.5% * STOCK SPECIFICS: ConocoPhillips (COP) traded higher to start the week as it announced it expects to repurchase USD 3bln worth of shares in 2020 as well as a 38% increase to its dividend, taking it to USD 0.42/shr. The latest moves express the commitment for COP to return more than 30% of cash from operations through dividends and buybacks. Nvidia (NVDA) saw a positive mention at RBC, which expects the name to be the best performing large cap within the next 6-9 months, citing a pickup in gaming demand and a recovery in the Nvidia data centre. General Motors (GM) initially opened lower after reports that talks with UAW had taken a turn for the worse as the automaker’s counteroffer was rejected; talks continue. General Electric’s (GE) move to reduce its pension deficit by USD 5-8bln saw the name in trade firmer, whereas Dollar Tree (DLTR) fell after its chairman disclosed a sale of 70k shares. In broker moves, Match (MTCH) was upgraded to buy at both Deutsche Bank and Nomura from hold and neutral, respectively; Moody’s (MCO) and E-trade (ETFC) were upgraded to buy from neutral at UBS; Citi upgraded Uber (UBER) to buy from neutral, as the bank is optimistic about a positive shift around sentiment regarding its core-ride sharing business. Wendy’s (WEN) were downgraded to market perform from outperform at Cowen, noting the breakfast menu launch does not create a long-term competitive advantage.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 12+ TICKS LOWER AT 131-16+: Treasuries, alongside EGBs, began treading lower in the European session as participants became cautiously optimistic in anticipation of US-China trade talks (reflective in major equity bourses, too), although some ominous updates ahead of the meetings failed to reverse the sell-off (it reversed the gains in equities), desks also noted dealer book squaring ahead of a heavy supply schedule at auctions later in the week. There was a pare back of last week’s bull steepening in anticipation of further Fed easing post the poor ISM data, with the overhang of Friday’s relatively decent payrolls report cooling some of the October cut pricing. Looking ahead, Fed Chair Powell is scheduled to provide remarks on monetary policy on Tuesday, too, where the market will be looking for some confirmation on whether the Fed is onboard with an October rate cut. At Treasury settlement yields were higher, seeing the curve bear flatten – 2s10s narrowed by 3.5bps, taking the spread back beneath 10bps.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 7th October 2019: Stocks reverse gains as China set to not budge on key issues
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities lower, Treasuries lower, Dollar higher, Crude lower.
  • REAR VIEW: China seemingly not to budge on key IP laws and government subsidies; Turkish forces begin aerial strikes on Kurdish forces as Trump removes US forces
  • UPCOMING: Data: German Industrial Output, US PPI Final Demand and EIA STEO. Speakers: BoE’s Carney and Tenreyro, ECB’s Lane and de Cos, Fed’s Powell, Evans and Kashkari. Supply: UK, Germany and US

 

* MARKET WRAP: Equity futures opened the week on the front foot, with negative developments in geopolitical tensions over the weekend involving the US, Hong Kong, China, North Korea, Syria, Turkey and Iran failing to manifest into risk appetite, before reversing course as it was reported China would not budge on subsidies and IP laws in approaching trade talks. The week sees US/China talks on Thursday/Friday, which is undoubtedly stealing the limelight, and the EU's deadline for substantial progress for Brexit talks also on Friday (allowing EU officials to mull the UK's proposal ahead of the 17/18th summit). As things stand, newsflow suggests there will be limited progress on both fronts, while a second whistle-blower has reportedly come forward in the Trump impeachment inquiry, further muddying the waters going into election season and potentially playing into foreign opponents’ hands in trade negotiations. Some, however, have argued that the primary concern should be the health of the US economy, following the recent run of mixed data; ahead, we have a speech from Fed Chair Powell on Tuesday (NOTE: Fed policymakers have generally not rung the economic alarm bells just yet), ahead of FOMC minutes on Wednesday, and then a CPI report later in the week, which will all be key in determining whether markets will trade on the 'Fed put' theme, where 'bad data is good' since it may incite Fed dovishness.

* CHINA TRADE: China officials are reportedly signalling they are increasingly reluctant to agree to a broad trade deal pursued by President Trump, Bloomberg reported, and officials have indicated the range of topics they’re willing to discuss has narrowed considerably, sources said. The source added that China's Vice Premier Liu He, who is due to attend negotiations on Thursday, has apparently said he will bring an offer that will not include commitments on reforming Chinese industrial policy, or government subsidies -- which would take a key Trump demand off the table; White House Trade Advisor Navarro repeating afterwards that the deal will have to be a big one, or there wouldn’t be one, didn’t provide reassurance. Later on, Fox reported a similar story, adding that China are prepared to set out a timetable for the harder issues to be worked out next year. China’s Commerce Ministry also stated that what is not in the table and never will be, is changes to their laws to protect IP, a key sticking point in talks, as are government subsidies. China is said to see itself having a stronger hand amid the impeachment crisis, although people close to the Trump administration have suggested a potential impeachment inquiry is not impacting trade talks. NEC Director Kudlow is one of those individuals, where he struck a cautiously optimistic tone later on Monday, stating that further progress could be made later this week and he is open to see what China brings to the table; Kudlow also noted that the delisting of Chinese corporates from the US is not on the table – walking back on previous media reports.

* FED: Fed's George (voter, hawkish dissenter) said if the US consumer were to lose confidence, the Fed might need to rethink its position on rates, but added she had a meeting-by-meeting approach. The Kansas Fed President reiterated that leaving rates unchanged at the September meeting would have been appropriate, and on inflation, that she would accept fluctuations of 100bps around the 2% target and that muted inflation would not warrant a policy response unless downside risks materialise. Fed's Kashkari (dove, voter in 2020) said he did not yet know by how much more the Fed should cut rates, but if a recession comes, then it would be appropriate to use QE.

* BREXIT: UK PM Johnson is reportedly seeking to launch legal action in his attempts to ensure that the UK can leave the EU this month with no deal. Several Government sources cited by the Telegraph said Johnson was willing to go to the Supreme Court in an effort to avoid complying with the so-called Benn Law, that would require him to write a letter asking for an A50 extension. The report also suggests that Johnson plans to 'sabotage' the EU if the UK remains a member beyond October 2019 by vetoing all decisions, and appointing a pro-Brexit commissioner into the new EU commission (with Brexit Party Leader Nigel Farage being touted), though analysts warned this plan may fail since the European Parliament must support Commission nominations. Other reports suggested AG Cox would resign if Johnson did not follow the (Benn) law. Separately, a Scottish Court dismissed a petition designed to force UK PM Johnson to request a Brexit extension should he fail to get a deal with the EU by 19th October, saying that “there can be no doubt that the first respondent [the PM] now accepts that he must comply with the requirements of the 2019 Act and has affirmed that he intends to do so.” The order would have barred him from sending a second letter telling the EU to ignore the request, delaying sending the letter or encouraging other member states to veto extension. Opponents of Johnson’s Brexit strategy, who were reportedly planning an "ambush" in parliament (where they would take control of parliamentary proceedings until an extension is secured) failed to come to an agreement today; the 21 Tory rebels who were expelled from the party reportedly want to give the PM more time to thrash out a deal with the EU, and have decided not to work against the government for now. Meanwhile, the opposition Labour and Liberal Democrat Parties are still unable to agree on who should lead a government of national unity (whose purpose would be to secure a Brexit extension), should the government lose a no confidence vote (the Lib Dems refuse to endorse Corbyn as a temporary PM), so the prospect of a vote of no confidence also appears to be on ice.

* SYRIA/TURKEY: In a major policy shift, the US announced it has begun withdrawing troops from the Northeast of Syria, a move which paves the way for Turkey to strike Kurdish-led forces (which were previously backed by the US to defeat ISIS in the region), there were reports later in the session Turkeyt had already begun striking Kurdish territories in the region, as US President Trump looks to extract his nation from 'endless wars'. The move has provoked both an international and domestic reaction for Trump - Republicans at home who have previously been supportive of Trump -- like Senator Graham Lindsay -- has denounced the move, and the lack of support shown to US' allies in the region. The move allows Turkey control over ISIS prisoners, which Kurdish forces have considered a 'stab in the back'. Turkey is now expected to mount the third incursion into Syrian territory since 2016 in an effort to contain the Syrian/Kurdish power; it has two objectives, 1) to push Kurdish YPG militia away from its border, and 2) to create a space inside Syria where 2mln Syrian refugees (currently based in Turkey) can be settled. France has warned Turkey against unilateral moves. The Pentagon itself said it does not endorse Turkish operations in Syria, and the US President himself warned prior to the evening’s attacks that if Turkey pursued any action that Trump "consider[s] to be off limits," then he has pledged to "totally destroy and obliterate the Economy of Turkey," adding that it is something he has done before.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 12+ TICKS LOWER AT 131-16+: Treasuries, alongside EGBs, began treading lower in the European session as participants became cautiously optimistic in anticipation of US-China trade talks (reflective in major equity bourses, too), although some ominous updates ahead of the meetings failed to reverse the sell-off (it reversed the gains in equities), desks also noted dealer book squaring ahead of a heavy supply schedule at auctions later in the week. There was a pare back of last week’s bull steepening in anticipation of further Fed easing post the poor ISM data, with the overhang of Friday’s relatively decent payrolls report cooling some of the October cut pricing. Looking ahead, Fed Chair Powell is scheduled to provide remarks on monetary policy on Tuesday, too, where the market will be looking for some confirmation on whether the Fed is onboard with an October rate cut. At Treasury settlement yields were higher, seeing the curve bear flatten – 2s10s narrowed by 3.5bps, taking the spread back beneath 10bps.

* US 3-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: The Treasury will this week auction a new 3-year note (USD 38bln, Tue), a 10-year re-opening (USD 24bln, Wed), and a 30-year bond re-opening (USD 16bln, Thu). Excluding SOMA holdings, there will be around USD 26bln of cash flows this week (around USD 24bln of redemptions, and USD 2bln of coupons). The complex lacks setup ahead of the auction from a relative value perspective, Societe Generale says, and trades rich in asset swap, and on the curve versus 2s and 5s. The bank thinks the sector appears expensive on an outright basis, with the current when-issued trading below all auction stop out rates since November 2016. The richening of 3s on the curve appears to be a result of the bull-steepening seen since the last auction. SocGen notes that after the recent, Treasuries appear to be consolidating and may be range-bound into the sale, though disruption is possible from geopolitics, of course. Low dealer holdings in the 3s bucket could be supportive of the auction, SocGen argues, though six of the last ten auctions have tailed, adding to the negatives.

* WTI (X9) SETTLED USD 0.06 LOWER AT USD 52.75/BBL; BRENT (Z9) SETTLED USD 0.02 LOWER AT USD 58.35/BBL: Crude markets were choppy on Monday, erasing losses seen at the futures open on Sunday night before reversing course into settlement amid back-and-forth China trade sentiment. OPEC's Secretary General Barkindo said they are relying on Russia to assist in smoothing tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia, and it is premature for OPEC to discuss additional oil output cuts, in-spite of the recent drop in prices. Providing supply concern was the Chinese State Oil Company pulling out of a USD 5bln deal to develop a portion of Iran’s offshore natural gas field amid the country’s escalating tensions with the US. Moreover, on Friday, reports emerged that the Buzzard oilfield in the North Sea (120k BPD) has been shut temporarily for pipework repairs, with no timeline on how quickly operations will return to normal. Elsewhere, Russian Energy Minister Novak said Russia should lower oil industry taxes and put into production some 10bln tonnes of oil reserves, before adding that Russia's oil output will decline in the coming years if it does not change taxation laws. Novak also said he considers a mid-term oil price in the USD 50-60/bbl range as fair. Participant in energy markets will be paying close attention to developments in US-China trade talks at the tail-end of the week, after digesting the monthly reports from the EIA (Oct. 8th), OPEC (Oct. 10th) and IEA (Oct. 11th), in addition to the weekly inventory reports. This week’s energy expectations are for crude stocks to show a build of 2.6mln bbls, distillates a draw of 2.3mln and gasoline a draw of 300k; Genscape forecasts Cushing stocks to build 348k.

* GEOPOLITICS (NK/HK): North Korea announced over the weekend that it has abandoned talks with the US. Following the two states’ nuclear talks in Sweden, the US reportedly came empty handed and has upheld its “hostile policy” against North Korea; desks note NK should remain a non-issue unless the country begins testing nuclear weapons and/or ballistic missiles. Further North, the unrest accumulated in Hong Kong too over the weekend – reports suggest protesters were shining lasers at a PLA garrison, in which the Chinese military responded by raising a flag warning the protestors they were in breach of the law and may be prosecuted. The actions of the PLA have raised concerns of Beijing coming closer to being deployed into Hong Kong, something that Chief Executive Carrie Lam can request, although is yet to do so in what would be the first use of said power in 50 years.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 -0.5% at 2939, NASDAQ-100 -0.4% at 7725, Dow Jones -0.4% at 26478

* SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  -0.4%, Consumer Staples  -0.8%, Energy  -0.9%, Financials  -0.5%, Health Care  -0.4%, Industrials  -0.5%, Information Technology  -0.5%, Materials  -0.3%, Telecommunication Services  0%, Utilities  -0.5%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: ConocoPhillips (COP) traded higher to start the week as it announced it expects to repurchase USD 3bln worth of shares in 2020 as well as a 38% increase to its dividend, taking it to USD 0.42/shr. The latest moves express the commitment for COP to return more than 30% of cash from operations through dividends and buybacks. Nvidia (NVDA) saw a positive mention at RBC, which expects the name to be the best performing large cap within the next 6-9 months, citing a pickup in gaming demand and a recovery in the Nvidia data centre. General Motors (GM) initially opened lower after reports that talks with UAW had taken a turn for the worse as the automaker’s counteroffer was rejected; talks continue. General Electric’s (GE) move to reduce its pension deficit by USD 5-8bln saw the name in trade firmer, whereas Dollar Tree (DLTR) fell after its chairman disclosed a sale of 70k shares. In broker moves, Match (MTCH) was upgraded to buy at both Deutsche Bank and Nomura from hold and neutral, respectively; Moody’s (MCO) and E-trade (ETFC) were upgraded to buy from neutral at UBS; Citi upgraded Uber (UBER) to buy from neutral, as the bank is optimistic about a positive shift around sentiment regarding its core-ride sharing business. Wendy’s (WEN) were downgraded to market perform from outperform at Cowen, noting the breakfast menu launch does not create a long-term competitive advantage.

* CANADA ELECTION DEBATE: Ahead of 21st October General Elections, leaders will hold a debate on Monday evening in English, and on Thursday in French. Current polling has PM Trudeau's Liberal Party (34.2%) slightly ahead of the Conservatives (33.7%). CBS said that, although the gap remains insignificant, the Liberals have moved ahead of the Conservatives in the national polling average for the first time since February; they are also ahead in the seat projection, though it is a toss-up whether they could secure a majority of seats. CBS added that neither the New Democrats nor the Greens have been able to build any significant momentum so far during this campaign, though the Bloc Québécois has gained.

* FX WRAP: EUR and CAD were range bound vs the buck ahead of key risks later in the week (trade, Fed minutes, CPI), with idiosyncratic developments in the form of bad German Industrial Output data, and firmer crude prices failing to provide much impetus. EURUSD remains bound between 1.0960 (Friday’s low) and 1.1000 (Thursday’s high) parameters, while Cable and USDCAD are supported ahead of the 1.2300 and 1.3300 marks respectively. Antipodes are lower, with the latest negative US/China trade headlines doing little to help; AUDUSD lost the 0.6750 mark while NZDUSD fell below 0.6300. Havens lost some ground today as XAU falls back beneath the 1500 level, and USDJPY breached 107 handle to the upside (the cross found resistance just shy of 107.50) likely supported by rate differentials as US yields picked up throughout the session; CHF was slightly firmer, however. The Scandies weakened, lead by SEK, with desks pointing to the recent run of bad data (PMIs and employment), recent gloomy Riksbank commentary and broader concerns over trade/global growth. EURSEK made fresh YTD highs, topping out just shy of 10.90 while EURNOK broke back above the 10.00 mark. In EMFX, TRY is the notable underperformer, after the US President Trump withdrew US forces from northern Syria, effectively opening the door for a Turkish invasion of the region. Trump also warned Turkey that if it were to do anything “off limits”, he would destroy and obliterate their economy.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Scandi Crowns underperform G10 counterparts, as Lira lags EM peers
content:
SEK/NOK/TRY

The Swedish Krona has dropped to the bottom of the major ranks as a negative combination of sub-50 PMIs, gloomy/dovish Riksbank remarks, broader jitters about global trade, growth and geopolitics finally triggered selling through the previous ytd low vs the Euro. In fact, Eur/Sek has now rallied to just shy of 10.9000 and Crown bears are now eyeing a Fib at 10.9452 ahead of the 11.0000 handle that Nordea is flagging for the cross by the end of 2019. Staying in Scandinavia, Eur/Nok is tagging along and now on a firmer footing above 10.0000 within 9.9778-10.0442 parameters, as some pundits predict an even weaker trajectory for Norway’s Crown given that Norges Bank has seemingly delivered its final 25 bp hike in the cycle. For the record, Eur/Nok’s all time high is circa 10.1700 and Nordea believes this could be surpassed by year end with the cross up to 10.2500. Meanwhile, the Lira is also under pressure on monetary policy grounds after latest benign if not outright or relatively soft Turkish inflation data upped the ante for more rate cuts. However, investors are wary about Turkey’s plans to take military action in Northern Syria and restart drilling off Cyprus as well, with Usd/Try up over 5.7900 at one stage.

AUD/NZD

Back to G10 land, the Antipodean Dollars remain on the back foot, albeit off worst levels between 0.6768-33 and 0.6321-0.6284 vs their US rival respectively, with latest US-China trade headlines/reports hardly conducive for the resumption of high level negotiations later this week. In short, Beijing is said to have scaled down its agenda for talks, while President Trump appears intent on reaching a comprehensive agreement rather than any interim accord.

CHF/EUR/CAD/GBP/JPY

All narrowly mixed and rangebound vs a fading Greenback, with the DXY losing its post-NFP recovery momentum as the index slips back from 98.989 to 98.738, but Usd/Chf has inched a bit further below 0.9950 and Eur/Usd touched 1.1000. Elsewhere, Usd/Cad dipped under 1.3300 amidst a gradual rise in crude prices and Cable is on a firmer 1.2300+ footing, but still wary about no deal Brexit risk after a petition designed to enforce the Benn extension bill was rejected pending appeal tomorrow. Usd/Jpy has not ventured far from 107.00 or mostly south of the big figure due to underlying safe-haven premium after US-NK talks broke down and US-Iran tensions continued, with the headline pair not really reacting to news that President Trump will be signing off on the US-Japanese trade deal later today.

Nomura see an end to the recent declines seen in global equities
content:
• Nomura see an end to the recent decline in global equities, and expect sentiment to head toward recovery as expected unless the US-China trade talks on 10-11 October bring additional bad news. Hedge fund positioning in US and Asian equities going into the US/China talks this week suggests two things, the bank argues. Firstly, the possibility that worries about downside for US equity could be fading and secondly, the possibility that global macro hedge funds and other investors may be expecting a further rally for Asian equities. Looking at hedge funds in the HFR global hedge fund index (HFRXGL), Nomura see that net exposure to US equity (30-day beta) fell sharply after last week's selloff. “We think this is because trend-following investors, as exemplified by CTAs, pared their US long positions on net, and/or cash-focused participants such as long/short funds built market-neutral positions” says the bank. Moreover, global macro hedge funds focused on top-down fundamentals appear to be building exposure to Asia equity, indicating that they may have begun factoring in a scenarios such as the US-China trade talks resulting in some sort of agreement favourable to China, leading to a bottoming in China's economy, and a resultant rally in Chinese and other Asia stocks.
  • Nomura estimate that CTAs will continue to pare their long equity futures positions, and the bank will be watching whether stock indices break through the major breakeven thresholds (2,970 for the S&P 500, 7,750 for the NDX, 26,680 for the DOW) heading toward the end of the week, which could halt any CTA long unwinding. Global macro hedge funds, the bank adds, have taken some profits on US equity long positions and closed out US bond short positions, and also look to have closed out all their US bond shorts by the end of last week in anticipation of disappointing US macro indicators.

US President Trump tweeted that China devalued its currency and "therefore paying the cost!", adds "we are helping the great farmers of the USA to the tune of USD 28bln, for the last two years, paid for out of tariffs paid to the US by China"

EU antitrust enforcer Vestager will signal a further clampdown on US tech giants by imposing an interim order on Broadcom (AVGO), according to FT (FT)

EU to ease restrictions on Japanese food imports, according to NHK World. (NHK)

Japan's Motegi says the US and Japan are to sign a trade agreement today in Washington. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities traded mixed after initially opening higher following the US jobs report, which was robust enough to temper recession fears but lacklustre enough to keep the Fed on track to cut rates again in October, albeit upside in the region is capped amid reports that China is narrowing scope for a trade deal with the US ahead of talks in Washington this week. ASX 200 (+0.7%) was kept afloat by mining names after base metals posted gains late Friday, meanwhile Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) traded lower throughout the session as exporters were pressured by an unfavourable currency. Elsewhere KOSPI (U/C) shrugged off the breakdown of North Korea/US denuclearisation dialogue on Sunday as South Korea focused on the upcoming large-cap earnings, with heavyweight Samsung Electronics expected to announce its Q3 guidance tomorrow. As a reminder, Hong Kong and Mainland China were closed due to public holidays.

In Hong Kong a second teenager has been shot in the leg by police and is in a serious condition, according to Sky News citing sources. It is not clear if the teenager was shot by a rubber bullet or a live round. (Newswires/Sky News)

Australian PM Morrison is reportedly rejecting calls to add new fiscal stimulus. (Newswires)

China Foreign Reserves (Sep) 3.092tln vs. Exp. 3.105tln – first decline in four months. (Newswires)

US

Fed's George (Voter, Dissenter, Hawk) said leaving US rates unchanged would have been appropriate, citing moderate growth, record-low unemployment and benign inflation outlook. If US consumer is losing confidence, the Fed might need to rethink position on rates, George says each meeting is a meeting to rethink views on rates. George added that it would be realistic to accept fluctuations by as much as 100 bps around the Fed's 2% target and currently, concerns about low inflation seems necessary, muted inflation would not warrant policy response unless downside risks materialise (Newswires)

A second whistle-blower has come forward in the impeachment inquiry against US President Trump, according to lawyers representing the first one. (BBC) Meanwhile, US President Trump allies reportedly pressed Ukraine over its state gas company, according to sources cited by AP. (AP) US President Trump accused House Speaker Pelosi of being as guilty of treason as House Intelligence Committee Chairman for his characterisation of the call with the Ukrainian President. (Newswires)

* CANADA ELECTION DEBATE: Ahead of 21st October General Elections, leaders will hold a debate tonight in English, and on Thursday in French. Current Polling has PM Trudeau's Liberal Party (34.2%) slightly ahead of the Conservatives (33.7%). CBS said that, alhough the gap remains insignificant, the Liberals have moved ahead of the Conservatives in the national polling average for the first time since February; they are also ahead in the seat projection, though it is a toss-up whether they could secure a majority of seats. (RANsquawk)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea has terminated working level nuclear talks with the US. North Korea’s Chief Nuclear Negotiator said it was “totally due to the fact that US would not give up its old viewpoints and attitude”. (Newswires)

Turkish President Erdogan and US President Trump discussed in a telephone conversation the plan to establish a safe area east of the Euphrates in Syria. Erdogan expressed unease with the US military and added that security bureaucracies are not doing what is necessitated by the agreement between US and Turkey. President Trump agreed to meet with Erdogan in Washington next month, upon Trump’s invitation. US White House confirmed the call between the two Presidents and notes that US will not be involved or stand in the way of Turkey's long planned operation into Northern Syria. Turkey will now be responsible for all ISIS fighters captured in Northern Syria. (Newswires)

Turkish Senior Official states that it is highly likely Turkey will wait until US soldiers have withdrawn from Northern Syria, could take one-week, before beginning offensive operations. (Newswires)

Japanese Government patrol boat is said to have collided with a North Korean fishing boat in the Japan North Sea, according to NHK, about 20 NK crew members are adrift in the Sea of Japan following the collision. (NHK) Japanese Fisheries Agency said the North Korean fishing boat was operating illegally. (Kyodo)

US President Trump is said to have ordered a substantial reduction in National Security Council Staff. (Newswires)

Iranian Oil Minister assured his Saudi counterpart that Iran did not start the dispute and that the enemies of the region abroad feed on the conflict between the two countries. (Al-Jezeera)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson is reportedly willing to go to the Supreme Court to avoid having to write a letter asking for a delay to Brexit, as set out in the Benn Act, according to sources. (Telegraph). Senior UK Government figures are reportedly considering a series of proposals to “sabotage” EU’s structure if Brussels does not agree to a new deal or lets UK PM Johnson leave the bloc without one, according to sources. Plans under consideration include blocking the EU’s 2021-27 budget which is due to be agreed early 2020. (Telegraph)

French President Macron said the EU will decide at the end of the week whether a Brexit deal is possible. (BBC) UK PM Johnson told French President Macron that he will not delay Brexit, spokesperson said the Britain will consider publishing a full legal text on proposals if deemed helpful. (Newswires)

A court will rule by noon today whether or not to issue an order that makes UK PM Johnson liable for "frustrating" the Benn Act, according to The Times' Swinford. (Twitter)

Portugal’s incumbent Prime Minister Costa’s Socialists won a general election on Sunday but fell short of an outright majority. The Socialist Party (PS) took 37% of the vote, followed by the centre-right Social Democrats (PSD) with 28%, with 98% of constituencies counted, according to the interior ministry. (Newswires)

Italy's Confindustria confirms 2019 GDP forecast of 0% and 0.4% in 2020 (assuming no increase in VAT), sees 2019 deficit gdp/ratio at 1.8% and 2020 at 2.8% (assuming no increase in VAT): subsequently, Italy's Economy Minister Gualtieri states that GDP growth forecast of +0.6% is a balanced and possibly even a cautious estimate for Italy. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European indices (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.2%) are little changed, after a weekend report alleged that China is narrowing scope for a trade deal with the US ahead of principle-level talks in Washington this week, with Chinese officials this week expected to offer a deal that doesn’t include anything on industrial policy or subsidies. Some desks tried to frame the reports as a positive, arguing that such concessions from China at this stage were very unlikely anyway, and adding that the article also talked about the possibility of the US and China making progress on a “mini deal” (where China could agree to making large-scale agricultural/energy purchases from the US and alter some IP practices in exchange for the US rolling back a partial amount of the existing tariffs). Such a mini deal, as hinted by the report, would likely exceed expectations for the talks, as most investors look for something more akin to a truce rather than any meaningful de-escalation. However, US President Trump has repeatedly shot down the prospect of any mini-deal, saying he would rather a full and comprehensive deal. As such, China’s refusal to engage with key US demands is likely to be seen as a negative for the long-term prospects of a comprehensive trade deal between the two sides. The sector layout is reflective of fragile risk sentiment; the defensive Utilities (0.3%), Consumer Staples (+0.4%) and Health Care (+0.6%) sectors are well supported while Consumer Discretionary (-0.1%), Tech (U/C) and Industrials (-0.1%) are underperforming. In terms of individual movers; Osram Licht (-4.3%) shares sunk after ASM (-3.3%) failed in its takeover bid for the Co., but said it would explore further strategic options to pursue the acquisition, with ASM shares pressured over investor concerns about the companies continued pursuit of the German lighting company. HSBC (-0.4%) shares were under pressure on the news that the Co. is to undertake a cost-cutting programme, which may affect 10k jobs. Bayer (2.5%) shares moved higher on the news that its October 15th trial date for the its US glyphosate case had been delayed until February 2020 (indicatively February 10th). Finally, LSE (U/C) opened higher after the Co. set a Wednesday deadline for the Hong Kong Exchange to place a revised takeover offer.

General Electric (GE) plans to reduce its pension deficit by roughly USD 5-8bln and freeze its US pension plan for about 20,000 employees with salaried benefits. (Newswires)

FX

AUD/NZD - The Aussie and Kiwi are bearing the brunt of renewed trade and geopolitical tensions having benefited from initial/brief Greenback weakness in the aftermath of last Friday’s ‘Goldilocks’ US jobs report. China is reportedly setting a limited agenda for talks in Washington this week, while discussions between the US and North Korea about denuclearisation were cut short over the weekend as an envoy from Pyongyang called for the Trump administration to withdraw hostile policy. Moreover, Turkey is back in the headlines with a resumption of drilling off Cyprus and operations in Northern Syria, while efforts to quell protests in Hong Kong have failed to prevent more violence and clashes. Aud/Usd is back below 0.6750 and Nzd/Usd has lost grip of the 0.6300 handle even though the Aud/Nzd cross is straddling 1.0700 amidst a bearish call from ANZ for the Kiwi to hit 0.5900 vs the Buck by Q1 next year.

SEK/GBP - The other major underperformers as the Swedish Krona continues to lament last week’s contractionary manufacturing and services PMIs alongside relatively downbeat Riksbank rhetoric via Jansson, while Sterling is suffering from fresh UK political and Brexit jitters following a lukewarm reception to PM Johnson’s proposals for the Irish border and ultimatum from the EU to alter the alternative plan by the end of the week. Eur/Sek just notched a new 2019 peak over 10.8700 and Cable has slipped back below 1.2300 with Eur/Gbp nestling above 0.8900.

CHF/JPY - In contrast to other G10 currencies, and despite the Dollar’s overall recovery from post-NFP lows (DXY nudging 99.000 again vs 98.720 at one stage on Friday), the Franc and Yen are both holding firm with Usd/Chf pivoting 0.9950, Eur/Chf hovering above 1.0900 and Usd/Jpy meandering between 107.02-106.58. Safe-haven positioning is impacting to an extent, while the Franc is also consolidating after recent quite hefty losses and the Yen is contained by decent option expiries in close proximity (1.5 bn at 106.70, 1.2 bn from 107.00-10 and 1.1 bn from 107.40-50).

EUR/CAD - The single currency is still hugging a tight line just under 1.1000 against the Greenback, and not too perturbed by yet more evidence of Eurozone economic woes in the form of German factory orders and Sentix sentiment, but the headline pair may constrained by expiry interest like Usd/Jpy given 1.4 bn sitting at 1.0950-60 and 1.1 bn at 1.0990-1.1000 into the NY cut. Elsewhere, the Loonie is trying to cap losses south of 1.3300 following Friday’s collapse in both measures of the Canadian Ivey PMI.

EM - Broad losses vs the Usd, with the Try undermined by the aforementioned Turkish factors and not deriving much in the way of support from President Erdogan lauding the CBRT for its policy actions, albeit anticipating more easing ahead. The Lira has been sub-5.7550, but now paring back.

ANZ forecasts NZD/USD to 0.5900 by end of March 2020 and 0.6100 by end of June next year, citing RBNZ lower cash rate and uncertainty surrounding capital decision, ANZ sees the OCR at 0.75% in May 2020 (currently 1.00%)

Notable Expiries, NY Cut:

- EUR/USD: 1.0900 (1BLN), 1.0925 (350M), 1.0950-60 (1.4BLN), 1.0975 (311M), 1.0990-1.1000 (1.1BLN), 1.1050 (370M)

- USD/JPY: 106.50-60 (600M), 106.70 (1.5BLN), 106.80-85 (700M), 107.00-10 (1.2BLN), 107.40-50 (1.1BLN)

FIXED

Far from an FTQ, but the 10 year German benchmark is edging higher and marginally extended the Eurex session peak at 174.72 (+23 ticks vs -4 ticks) in wake of yet more worrying Eurozone data and survey releases, with Gilts up in the slipstream to 134.95 (+5 ticks vs -17 ticks at worst) amidst the ongoing Brexit stalemate and pressure on PM Johnson to come up with a deal or go back to Brussels and ask for more time. However, US Treasuries remain reticent and the curve is marginally steeper ahead of more jobs data and Fed speak.

COMMODITIES

Crude markets advanced on Monday, erasing losses seen at the futures open on Sunday night, where prices had initially been pressured by seemingly negative US/China trade headlines over the weekend; WTI Nov’ 19 and Brent Nov’ 19 futures have reclaimed the USD 53.00/bbl and USD 58.50/bbl levels to the upside respectively. Supply side factors could be providing some support; Chinese State Oil Company pulled out of a USD 5bln deal to develop a portion of Iran’s offshore natural gas field amid the country’s escalating tensions with the US. Moreover, on Friday, reports emerged that the Buzzard oilfield in the North Sea has been shut temporarily for pipework repairs, with no timeline on how quickly operations will return to normal. The Buzzard field is the key contributor to the Forties blend, says Platts, and output at the field has been running at around 120k bpd. ING conclude that “an extended outage would likely provide some relative support to Brent”. Elsewhere, Russian Energy Minister Novack said Russia should lower oil industry taxes and put into production some 10bln tonnes of oil reserves, before adding that Russia's oil output will decline in the coming years if it does not change taxation laws. Novak also said he considers a mid-term oil price in the USD 50s are fair. In terms of metals, Copper and Gold prices moved lower on Monday but are cautious within recent ranges ahead of this week’s key risk events, which include US/China trade talks, FOMC and ECB Minutes, US CPI and a slew of Fed speak including a triple appearance from Fed Chair Powell. ING observe that the PBOC added 0.19mln/oz of gold to its reserves in the month of September, taking total reserves to 62.64mln/oz, a tenth consecutive month of gold purchases by China, which the bank says reflects the diversification drive away from the US dollar at a time of trade friction with the US. “Gold demand from Central Banks and ETFs has been stronger this year on economic and geopolitical concerns” the bank adds, “however higher prices have started to weigh on retail demand”, which recently is most evident in the large fall in demand by its usual largest buyer, India.

Chinese State Oil Company has pulled out of a USD 5bln deal to develop a portion of Iran’s offshore natural gas field amid escalating tensions with the US. (SCMP)

OPEC's Secretary General Barkindo says they are relying on Russia to assist in smoothing tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia, and it is premature for OPEC to discuss additional oil output cuts, in-spite of the recent drop in prices., Tass. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak says Russia should lower oil industry taxes and put into production some 10bln tonnes of oil reserves, says Russia's oil output will decline in the coming years if it does not change taxation; mid-term oil price of USD 50/bbl seen as fair. (Newswires)

subject: Plans for a cross-party group of anti-no deal MPs to stage an "ambush" in parliament is "on ice" for now, with UK PM Johnson's opponents "not on the same page"
content:
• Via Twitter
  • This follows earlier reports that a cross-party group of MPs was hoping to stage ambush in Parliament in next couple of days, designed to make it easier for them to take control of Commons agenda to block a no deal Brexit. (Via Twitter)
analysis_details: • Reportedly, it was the 21 Tory MPs who had been expelled from the Conservative party (plus Amber Rudd who quit) who today refused to support opposition MPs who wanted to put down an SO24 motion that would have allowed MPs to seize control of parliament’s business on any day between now and 31 October; now it won’t be put on the order paper till next Tuesday, if at all. "The Tory rebels apparently now buy the Johnson and Cummings argument that MPs flexing their collective muscles to stop a no-deal Brexit is undermining their chances of getting a deal"., ITV's Peston

content: The Short Sterling strip is clinging to an underlying bid between -0.5 and +1 tick compared to previous settlement levels, but Gilts are underperforming alongside US Treasuries in wake of the net bullish reaction to Friday’s NFP release and the 10 year UK benchmark’s failure to breach 135.00. Softer than forecast Halifax house prices have been largely shrugged off as domestic markets await further Brexit and political developments given another deadline to break the Irish border deadlock before next week’s EU Summit, assuming PM Johnson is not forced to comply with the Benn Act calling for another Article 50 extension and the EU agrees to extend the current October 31 end date of course. In the interim, a light UK agenda until Thursday’s flurry of data, though BoE Governor Carney and MPC member Haldane are both slated to speak tomorrow. Back to Liffe, Gilts are holding nearer the base of a 134.91-73 band vs Friday’s 134.90 close.

content: A relatively subdued start to Monday’s Eurex session, but the core Eurozone bond is back above parity within a 174.45-63 range vs last Friday’s 174.49 close in wake of more disappointing German data and broader risk-off sentiment fuelled by more unrest in Hong Kong over the weekend, a breakdown in talks between the US and North Korea and reports that China is setting its sights low ahead of trade talks in Washington later this week. Next up, Sentix economic sentiment is expected to deteriorate further, while some calendars are flagging a speech by ECB’s de Cos at some stage.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

7th October 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equities traded mixed after initially opening higher following the US jobs report, which was robust enough to temper recession fears but lacklustre enough to keep the Fed on track to cut rates again in October, albeit upside in the region is capped amid reports that China is narrowing scope for a trade deal with the US ahead of talks in Washington this week. ASX 200 (+0.7%) was kept afloat by mining names after base metals posted gains late Friday, meanwhile Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) traded lower throughout the session as exporters were pressured by an unfavourable currency. Elsewhere KOSPI (+0.2%) shrugged off the breakdown of North Korea/US denuclearisation dialogue on Sunday as South Korea focused on the upcoming large-cap earnings, with heavyweight Samsung Electronics expected to announce its Q3 guidance tomorrow. As a reminder, Hong Kong and Mainland China were closed due to public holidays.

FTSE 100

HSBC (HSBA LN) – Co. are reportedly to undertake a cost-cutting programme, which may affect 10k jobs; individuals note this has the potential to result in a significant reduction of the Co’s headcount. (FT)

Tesco (TSCO LN) – Sir John Kingman is expected to be announced as the new Chairman of Tesco Bank. (Newswires)

Vodafone (VOD LN) – Co. are trialling open-access-radio technology in Britain, which is the first instance of this being utilised within Europe. (Newswires) Of note for Ericsson (ERICB SS) & Nokia (NOKIA FH)

LSE (LSE LN) – Wednesday is the deadline for the Hong Kong Exchange to place a revised deal for the Co. (FT/Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Bayer (BAYN GY) – October 15th trial date for the Co’s US glyphosate case has been delayed until February 2020, indicatively February 10th. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Osram Licht (OSR GY) – Co. are to update their strategy; have also invited AMS (AMS SW) for discussions, as AMS has not achieved sufficient shares to secure their EUR 4.5bln bid for Osram; final acceptance level 51.6% (62.5% required). Separately, Advent & Bain are considering a new offer for the Co. (Newswires)

ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) – CEO Marz is expected to update the Co’s top management on Tuesday. (Newswires)

Porsche (PAH3 GY) – Hankook Tire is to be the Co’s tyre supplier from their Cayenne vehicles in June. (Newswires) Potentially of note for Pirelli (PIRC IM) and Continental (CON GY).

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – EU regulators have begun a probe into Boeing (BA) and Embraer’s (ERJ) deal, due to concerns regarding competition; decision is expected to be announced by February 2020. Separately, Co. are reportedly planning on the launch of their own exchange to allow airlines to hedge sterling revenue. (Newswires/FT)

Societe Generale (GLE FP) – Co’s CEO has stated that the ECB should not undertake the purchase of bank bonds. (FT)

PUBLICIS (PUB FP) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Schneider Electric (SU FP) – Co. are entering a strategic partnership with ThoughtWire, for combined health-care facilities. (Newswires)

Altran (ALT FP) – Capgemini (CAP FP) have received Moroccan anti-trust approval for their takeover of the Co; deal is valued at around EUR 3.6bln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Tech Co’s – EU Competition Commissioner Vestager is reportedly to indicate a additional clampdown on US tech Co’s this month, through the imposition of a interim order which will force Broadcom (AVGO) to stop their alleged anti-competitive undertakings, prior to the resolution of the investigation into the Co. (FT)

Telefonica (TEF SM) – Co. are reportedly entering a agreement with Brazilian competitors regarding the acquisition of Oi., according to Spanish press. (Newswires)

SMI

Novartis (NOVN SW) – AveXis, Co’s subsidiary, has announced new interim data for their Phase 1-2 study. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

Telecom Names – JP Morgan state they are cautious on the Nordic Telecom sector for Q3. (Newswires)

Aker (AKER NO) – Co. state that production from the Johan Sverdrup field has begun over two months ahead of schedule and approx. NOK 40bln under budget; plateau production is approx. 440k BPD. Also of note for Total (FP FP) (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ERICSSON (ERICB SS) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM SELL AT SEB ENSKILDA

US

*S&P CLOSED +1.4% AT 2952.00, NASDAQ100 +1.4% AT 7982.5 AND DJIA +1.4% AT 26573.2

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 7th October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equities traded mixed after initially opening higher, Mainland China and Hong Kong were closed
  • China is narrowing scope for a trade deal with the US ahead of principle-level talks in Washington this week, according to reports
  • North Korea has terminated working level nuclear talks with the US due to US’ “old viewpoints and attitude”, according to NK
  • UK PM Johnson is reportedly willing to go to the Supreme Court to avoid having to write a letter asking for a delay to Brexit
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Industrial Orders, US Consumer Credit, Fed’s Powell & Kashkari

TRADE

China is narrowing scope for a trade deal with the US ahead of principle-level talks in Washington this week, reports stated. Chinese officials this week are expected to come with an offer that doesn’t include anything on industrial policy or subsidies. Meanwhile on Friday, US President Trump said we have a very good chance of making a deal with China. (Newswires) Note: US equity futures gapped lower at the open amid the reports.

US President Trump tweeted that China devalued its currency and "therefore paying the cost!", adds "we are helping the great farmers of the USA to the tune of USD 28bln, for the last two years, paid for out of tariffs paid to the US by China"

EU regulators have opened a probe into Boeing (BA) and Embraer (ERJ) deal, citing competition concerns; will decide by February 2020. (Newswires) Further, EU antitrust enforcer Vestager will signal a further clampdown on US tech giants by imposing an interim order on Broadcom (AVGO), according to FT (FT)

EU to ease restrictions on Japanese food imports, according to NHK World. (NHK)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities traded mixed after initially opening higher following the US jobs report, which was robust enough to temper recession fears but lacklustre enough to keep the Fed on track to cut rates again in October, albeit upside in the region is capped amid reports that China is narrowing scope for a trade deal with the US ahead of talks in Washington this week. ASX 200 (+0.7%) was kept afloat by mining names after base metals posted gains late Friday, meanwhile Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) traded lower throughout the session as exporters were pressured by an unfavourable currency. Elsewhere KOSPI (+0.2%) shrugged off the breakdown of North Korea/US denuclearisation dialogue on Sunday as South Korea focused on the upcoming large-cap earnings, with heavyweight Samsung Electronics expected to announce its Q3 guidance tomorrow. As a reminder, Hong Kong and Mainland China were closed due to public holidays.

Hong Kong court declined an injunction to suspend the anti-mask law. Separately, a second teenager has been shot in the leg by police and is in a serious condition, according to Sky News citing sources. It is not clear if the teenager was shot by a rubber bullet or a live round. (Newswires/Sky News)

Australian PM Morrison is reportedly rejecting calls to add new fiscal stimulus. (Newswires)

China Foreign Reserves (Sep) 3.092tln vs. Exp. 3.105tln – first decline in four months. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson is reportedly willing to go to the Supreme Court to avoid having to write a letter asking for a delay to Brexit, as set out in the Benn Act, according to sources. (Telegraph) Additionally, UK PM Johnson reportedly reiterated that we will either have a new deal or a no deal but will not endorse a delay. (Newswires) Senior UK Government figures are reportedly considering a series of proposals to “sabotage” EU’s structure if Brussels does not agree to a new deal or lets UK PM Johnson leave the bloc without one, according to sources. Plans under consideration include blocking the EU’s 2021-27 budget which is due to be agreed early 2020. (Telegraph)

UK PM Johnson reportedly reiterated that we will either have a new deal or a no deal but will not endorse a delay. (Newswires)

EU diplomats have been briefed by the EU Commission that discussions are in a stalemate, citing the UK as not budging on custom checks and the timed backstop veto (Stormont veto). (FT) EU sources said Member States agreed that the UK proposals do not provide a basis for concluding an agreement; PM Johnson requested weekend talks on his Irish backstop proposals, but Commission doesn’t see more discussions as useful at this stage. (Newswires) Further, French President Macron said the EU will decide at the end of the week whether a Brexit deal is possible. (BBC) UK PM Johnson told French President Macron that he will not delay Brexit, spokesperson said the Britain will consider publishing a full legal text on proposals if deemed helpful. (Newswires)

Portugal’s incumbent Prime Minister Costa’s Socialists won a general election on Sunday but fell short of an outright majority. The Socialist Party (PS) took 37% of the vote, followed by the centre-right Social Democrats (PSD) with 28%, with 98% of constituencies counted, according to the interior ministry. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Belgium at 'AA-'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS 

North Korea has terminated working level nuclear talks with the US. North Korea’s Chief Nuclear Negotiator said it was “totally due to the fact that US would not give up its old viewpoints and attitude”. (Newswires)

Apparent Iranian government-linked hacking operation targeted US President Trump’s re-election campaign, attempt was unsuccessful, sources said. (Newswires)

Turkish President Erdogan and US President Trump discussed in a telephone conversation the plan to establish a safe area east of the Euphrates in Syria. Erdogan expressed unease with the US military and added that security bureaucracies are not doing what is necessitated by the agreement between US and Turkey. President Trump agreed to meet with Erdogan in Washington next month, upon Trump’s invitation. US White House confirmed the call between the two Presidents and notes that US will not be involved or stand in the way of Turkey's long planned operation into Northern Syria. Turkey will now be responsible for all ISIS fighters captured in Northern Syria. (Newswires)

Japanese Government patrol boat is said to have collided with a North Korean fishing boat in the Japan North Sea, according to NHK, about 20 NK crew members are adrift in the Sea of Japan following the collision. (NHK) Japanese Fisheries Agency said the North Korean fishing boat was operating illegally. (Kyodo)

US President Trump is said to have ordered a substantial reduction in National Security Council Staff. (Newswires)

Iranian Oil Minister assured his Saudi counterpart that Iran did not start the dispute and that the enemies of the region abroad feed on the conflict between the two countries. (Al-Jezeera)

FX

 

In FX, the DXY traded sideways within a narrow intraday band ahead of this week’s key risk events which include US/China trade talks, FOMC and ECB Minutes, US CPI and a slew of Fed speak including a triple appearance from Fed Chair Powell. EUR/USD and GBP/USD traded flat above 1.0975 and 1.2300 respectively, with sources noting that UK PM Johnson is poised to go to the Supreme court to avoid having to write a letter to the EU asking for an another Article 50 extension, which comes as the PM’s Brexit proposals look increasingly unlikely to morph into a deal. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was initially subdued as reports of China narrowing its scope for a trade deal coupled with the breakdown in North Korea and US talks caused the pair to gap lower at the open, USD/JPY remained sub-107.00 with 1.6bln in options expiring at strike 106.70 at the NY cut. AUD/USD and NZD/USD were choppy and were subdued by the aforementioned China news, albeit more so the Aussie, as the pair tested 0.6750 to the downside and briefly dipped through the level. Meanwhile, Kiwi fared slightly better as the AUD/NZD cross fell back below the 1.07 mark, however some downside in NZD/USD coincided with ANZ forecasting the pair at 0.5900 by the end of March 2020, citing a lower OCR and uncertainty surrounding capital decision. Finally, USD/CNH gapped above 7.12 at the open (vs. a Friday close ~7.1080) and reached a high just shy of 7.1400 before drifting lower.

ANZ forecasts NZD/USD to 0.5900 by end of March 2020 and 0.6100 by end of June next year, citing RBNZ lower cash rate and uncertainty surrounding capital decision, ANZ sees the OCR at 0.75% in May 2020 (currently 1.00%)

COMMODITIES

 

WTI and Brent futures moved sideways after gapping lower at the open as the prospect of a US-China trade deal this week receded after reports stated that the range of topics China is willing to discuss has considerably narrowed. WTI fell back below 53/bbl while Brent traded just above 58/bbl (below its 200 WMA at 58.40/bbl) throughout the Asia-Pac session. Gold posted modest gains as the aforementioned China reports saw some flight to safety at the open, albeit most of the gains dissipated throughout the session. Copper remained flat and held onto its NFP-induced gains as the red metal sets eyes on this week’s risk events.

Chinese State Oil Company has pulled out of a USD 5bln deal to develop a portion of Iran’s offshore natural gas field amid escalating tensions with the US. (SCMP)

Motiva Port Arthur Texas Refinery (636k BPD) is to shut its small coker early next week for maintenance, according to sources. (Newswires)

Baker Hughes: Oil rigs -3 at 710, NatGas rigs down 2 at 144; Total rigs down 5 at 855. (Newswires)

US

* US T-NOTE (Z9) FUTURES SETTLE 5 TICKS HIGHER AT 131-29: Treasuries are mixed at the end of the week, though the bias is towards a flatter curve. The T-Note future surged immediately after the release of the September payrolls report, with traders raising bets that the data would lead to a Fed rate cut at the October meeting; the implied probability of an October cut started the week at around 40%, rising to 90% at one point in wake of grim ISM data, though is around 75% as we close out the week; that is despite the constructive tone of Fedspeak, where Chair Powell and Vice Chair Clarida seeing the economy in a good place. Meanwhile, the NY Fed has said it is extending its repo operations through 4th November, at the size of USD 75bln.

Fed Chair Powell repeated economy is in a good place despite some risks; inflation running close to, but below Fed's 2% target. (Newswires)

Fed's George (Voter, Dissenter, Hawk) said leaving US rates unchanged would have been appropriate, citing moderate growth, record-low unemployment and benign inflation outlook. If US consumer is losing confidence, the Fed might need to rethink position on rates, George says each meeting is a meeting to rethink views on rates. George added that it would be realistic to accept fluctuations by as much as 100 bps around the Fed's 2% target and currently, concerns about low inflation seems necessary, muted inflation would not warrant policy response unless downside risks materialise (Newswires)

Fed’s Rosengren (Voter, Dissenter, Hawk) said we have to keep in mind where we are in the cycle, we have low unemployment and inflation is near the 2% target, so a pace of jobs between 90-150k a month is normal for a healthy economy. Rosengren added that the overall US economic growth will be around 1.7% for Q3/Q4 in 2019 and the data in recent weeks is not a complete surprise, tariffs effecting both manufacturing and exports. Further, he said indicators for consumer spending remain strong and monetary policy is currently accommodative. (Newswires)

Fed's Mester (Non-voter, Hawk) said she is data-dependent and the US economy doing pretty well, jobs report was good; Fed knew economy would slow this year; headwinds on trade must be taken seriously. (CNBC)

Fed's Bostic (Non-voter, Dove) said stimulus is intended to address weaknesses and assist the economy through difficulties; and added that Fed is trying to determine if the economy is heading towards a soft or hard landing. (Newswires)

A second whistle-blower has come forward in the impeachment inquiry against US President Trump, according to lawyers representing the first one. (BBC) Meanwhile, US President Trump allies reportedly pressed Ukraine over its state gas company, according to sources cited by AP. (AP) US President Trump accused House Speaker Pelosi of being as guilty of treason as House Intelligence Committee Chairman for his characterisation of the call with the Ukrainian President. (Newswires) Key documents related to Ukraine are sought from US VP Pence by House committees. (US House)

subject: PRE-MARKET INDIA STOCK NEWS:The Reserve Bank of India cut rates by 25bps, as was expected, and continued to leave the door open to further reductions (its official stance remains "accommodative")
content:
INDIA

YES Bank (YES IS) – Co. is reportedly in talks with Microsoft about a strategic investment, the bank could sell up to a 15% equity stake. Further, TPG, The Carlyle Group and Farallon Capital are reportedly seeking to buy large strategic stakes in the Co. (Newswires/ET)

Reliance Home Finance (RELHOME IS) – Co. is in discussions with several investors for equity infusion. (ET)

PNG (PNG IS) – Managing director says there is no second wave of bad loans, but some unexpected cases have come up. (ET)

- The Reserve Bank of India cut rates by 25bps, as was expected, and continued to leave the door open to further reductions (its official stance remains "accommodative"). The rate cut was the fifth this year, and was sized at 25bps, as opposed to the 35bps cut seen at the previous MPC. The repo rate now stands at 5.15%, lowest since 2010. The RBI said the decision was driven by the recent economic weakness. The RBI also trimmed its growth forecast for the year to 6.1% (from 6.9%) and stated that "the continuing slowdown warrants intensified efforts to restore the growth momentum." (RANsquawk)

- Analysts see disappointing Q2 earnings amid tighter liquidity. (Newswires)
